Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi everyone,

Did anyone else find it problematic that the NeuronGeneId was=
 generated just like the InnovationId for the ConnectionGene? In my impleme=
ntation, I decided to use a GUID for gene identification, and only use the =
innovation number for sequencing (aging) the connection genes - substantial=
ly reducing the range of the innovation numbers.

The search space for iden=
tifying identical preexisting connections is always problematic (due to the=
 time penalty it imposes), even if done efficiently. How about a small stat=
ic structure similar to a step function CPPN (ok, just an array, diagonaliz=
ed of course) to take the endpoints of connections as inputs and generate a=
 value (1 or (true) =3D prior exists, 0 =3D it doesn't).  Here, using the e=
ndpoint GUIDs keeps the array small enough, only encoding surviving searcha=
ble neurons.

Ken Lloyd


From: Colin Green 
Sent: Thursday, June 25, 2009 =
6:31 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
Subject: [neat] Re: about the innovation =
number





Hi,

Yes, typically a NEAT implementation will have some means =
of comparing new connections (and sometime's neurons) with all of the conne=
ctions currently present in the population as a whole. If this comparison r=
esults in a match then you can re-use the innovation number, otherwise you =
take the next free innovation number.

Therefore to achieve the same functi=
onaility when running on multiple machines you would need to compare the ne=
w connection with the complete population across all machines.

On the othe=
r hand I'm not sure the existing NEAT implementations strictly adhere to in=
novation re-use, e.g. rather than maintaining a hashtable of all connection=
s it may be quicker and alomst as good to maintain a hashtable of the last =
N new connections, thus introducing the possibility of a new connection bei=
ng allocated a new innovation number even though there exists a matching co=
nnection elsewhere.

Colin.
